ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle:
Local structure of Fe-doped
In 2
O 3
$\mathrm{In}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ films investigated by X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Key Laboratory of Display Materials and Photoelectric Devices, Ministry of Education; Tianjin Key Laboratory for Photoelectric Materials and Devices; School of Material Science and Engineering
Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility (BSRF), Institute of High Energy Physics

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
(
In
1 − x
Fe x
)
2
O 3
$(\mathrm{In}_{1-x}\mathrm{Fe}_{x})_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$
( x = 0.07 , 0.09 , 0.16 , 0.22 , 0.31 )
$(x=0.07, 0.09, 0.16, 0.22, 0.31)$ films were deposited on Si (100) substrates by RF-magnetron sputtering technique. The influence of Fe doping on the local structure of films was investigated by X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) at Fe K-edge and L-edge. For the
(
In
1 − x
Fe x
)
2
O 3
$(\mathrm{In}_{1-x}\mathrm{Fe}_{x})_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ films with
x = 0.07 , 0.09 and 0.16
$x=0.07, 0.09 \mbox{ and } 0.16$ , Fe ions dissolve into
In 2
O 3
$\mathrm{In}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ and substitute for
In
3 +
$\mathrm{In}^{3+}$ sites with a mixed-valence state (
Fe
2 +
/
Fe
3 +
$\mathrm{Fe}^{2+}/\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$ ) of Fe ions. However, a secondary phase of Fe metal clusters is formed in the
(
In
1 − x
Fe x
)
2
O 3
$(\mathrm{In}_{1-x}\mathrm{Fe}_{x})_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ films with
x = 0.22 and 0.31
$x=0.22 \mbox{ and } 0.31$ . The qualitative analyses of Fe-K edge extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) reveal that the Fe–O bond length shortens and the corresponding Debye–Waller factor (
σ 2
$\sigma^{2}$ ) increases with the increase of Fe concentration, indicating the relaxation of oxygen environment of Fe ions upon substitution. The anomalously large structural disorder and very short Fe–O distance are also observed in the films with high Fe concentration. Linear combination fittings at Fe L-edge further confirm the coexistence of
Fe
2 +
$\mathrm{Fe}^{2+}$ and
Fe
3 +
$\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$ with a ratio of
∼ 3 : 2
${\sim}3:2$ (
Fe
2 +
:
Fe
3 +
$\mathrm{Fe}^{2+}: \mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$ ) for the
(
In
1 − x
Fe x
)
2
O 3
$(\mathrm{In}_{1-x}\mathrm{Fe}_{x})_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ film with
x = 0.16
$x=0.16$ . However, a significant fraction (
∼ 40
at%
${\sim}40~\mbox{at\%}$ ) of the Fe metal clusters is found in the
(
In
1 − x
Fe x
)
2
O 3
$(\mathrm{In}_{1-x}\mathrm{Fe}_{x})_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ film with
x = 0.31
$x=0.31$ .

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
Recently, diluted magnetic semiconductors (DMSs) have attracted a great deal of interest due to their tremendous potential application in spintronics [1, 2]. Since the mean-field theory of ferromagnetism by Dietl et al. predicted that room-temperature (RT) ferromagnetism may be realized in wide-bandgap semiconductors [3], numerous oxide-based semiconductors, such as ZnO [4–6],
TiO 2
$\mathrm{TiO}_{2}$ [7, 8],
SnO 2
$\mathrm{SnO}_{2}$ [9, 10] and
In 2
O 3
$\mathrm{In}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ [11–14], have increasingly triggered considerable attention. Being one of these candidate hosts,
In 2
O 3
$\mathrm{In}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ is a technologically important n-type wide-bandgap (3.75 eV) semiconductor and has wide potential applications in electronics and optics, including flat-panel displays and gas sensors. In general, the solubility of transition metals (TM), especially Fe, can reach up to 20 % into the
In 2
O 3
$\mathrm{In}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ . Also, the large magnetic moment among those of 3d TM atoms, Fe (
∼ 2.2
μ B
/ atom
${\sim}2.2~\mu_{\mathrm{B}}/\mbox{atom}$ ) is the optimum candidate as a magnetic dopant. So far, much attention has been paid to potential DMS behaviors of
In 2
O 3
$\mathrm{In}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ . However, these experimental results and conclusions obtained by different research groups are quite different and even contradictory. Yu et al. reported RT ferromagnetic Fe- and Cu-codoped
In 2
O 3
$\mathrm{In}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ films, and confirmed that the ferromagnetism is mediated by mobile carriers [15]. However, Li et al. reported that the RT ferromagnetism in Fe-doped
In 2
O 3
$\mathrm{In}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ films with Sn codoping is not due to charge carriers but is directly related to oxygen vacancies [16]. Jayakumar et al. discovered ferromagnetism in Fe-doped
In 2
O 3
$\mathrm{In}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ powders [17]. However, Peleckis et al. found that Fe-doped
In 2
O 3
$\mathrm{In}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ bulk samples prepared by a conventional solid-state reaction exhibited paramagnetic behavior [18]. Yoo et al. reported that ferromagnetism could be achieved in Fe- and Cu-codoped
In 2
O 3
$\mathrm{In}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ bulk sample [19], while Chu et al. failed to found the ferromagnetism in the Fe- and Cu-codoped
In 2
O 3
$\mathrm{In}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ prepared by co-precipitation synthesis method [20]. The ferromagnetism often results from the precipitation of metallic ferromagnetic clusters or secondary magnetic phases and is very sensitive to the growth conditions, such as preparation method, growth temperature, oxygen pressure and doping concentration. In order to clarify the mechanisms responsible for the ferromagnetic order in this system, it is important to study the formation of clusters as well as local atomic and electronic structures around Fe atoms. XAS measurements at Fe K-edge and L-edge are very useful for determining the chemical valence states and local structure of incorporated Fe atoms in
In 2
O 3
$\mathrm{In}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ system even in a dilute concentration. In particular, XAS can see the Fe metal components even if they are disordered or in small nanoparticles. In this paper, we employed XAS tool to investigate the local structure of Fe-doped
In 2
O 3
$\mathrm{In}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ films. The influence of Fe doping on the local structure was qualitatively analyzed. These results can provide new structural information useful for material design and lay a strong foundation for discussing the origin of ferromagnetism in Fe-doped
In 2
O 3
$\mathrm{In}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ system.

Section1.Heading: Experimental details
Section1.Para:
Fe-doped
In 2
O 3
$\mathrm{In}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ films about 340-nm thick were deposited on (001) Si substrates by RF-magnetron sputtering. The base pressure of the sputter deposition chamber was about
8 ×
10
− 5
Pa
$8\times10^{-5}~\mbox{Pa}$ . The films were sputtered in 0.8 Pa of pure argon at a substrate temperature of 400 °C. The Fe concentration in the films was determined as 7, 9, 16, 22 and 31 at% by the X-ray energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). The Fe K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) measurements were performed in the total fluorescence mode at Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility (BSRF) on the 4B9A beamline of X-ray diffraction station. The Fe
L
2 , 3
$\mathrm{L}_{2,3}$ -edge XAS spectra were measured by the total electron-yield mode at Beijing Synchrotron Radiation (BSRF) on the 4B9B beamline of X-ray photoemission spectroscopy station. Reference spectra of Fe foil,
Fe 2
O 3
$\mathrm{Fe}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ , FeO and
Fe 3
O 4
$\mathrm{Fe}_{3}\mathrm{O}_{4}$ foil were also measured for comparison and data analysis purposes.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
The XANES/EXAFS techniques have been established as a powerful method to understand the local structure of TM-doped oxide systems. XANES is a fingerprint of the valence state and neighbor environment of TM cations in the host matrix and is highly sensitive to the precipitation of metal clusters or secondary magnetic phases, whereas the quantitative structural information about the metal environment can be obtained from the EXAFS analysis. Figure 1(a) shows the Fe K-edge XANES spectra of
(
In
1 − x
Fe x
)
2
O 3
$(\mathrm{In}_{1-x}\mathrm{Fe}_{x})_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ (
x = 0.07 , 0.09 , 0.16 , 0.22 , 0.31
$x=0.07, 0.09, 0.16, 0.22, 0.31$ ) films. As a guide to the valence state of Fe ions, reference Fe K-edge XANES spectra of standard Fe metal and Fe oxides (
Fe 2
O 3
$\mathrm{Fe}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ ,
Fe 3
O 4
$\mathrm{Fe}_{3}\mathrm{O}_{4}$ and FeO) are also displayed. One can see that three peaks, which are the main peaks B and C, and a shoulder peak A appearing at the lower energy side of peak B, are observed in the reference spectra of Fe oxides. However, there only exist two peaks (a and b) in the
(
In
1 − x
Fe x
)
2
O 3
$(\mathrm{In}_{1-x}\mathrm{Fe}_{x})_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ (
x ≤ 0.22
$x\leq0.22$ ) films and the energy difference between a and b is also smaller than the one between B and C in the reference spectra. These indicate that the surrounding environment of the doped Fe atoms is rather different from those of standard Fe oxides. So the existence of Fe oxides can be safely excluded in these Fe-doped
In 2
O 3
$\mathrm{In}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ films. It is possible that Fe atoms are substituted for In atoms in
In 2
O 3
$\mathrm{In}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ . When
x
$x$ is up to 0.31, the peak b shifts to a higher energy position and the energy difference between a and b also becomes large. The XANES spectral features of the
(
In 0.69
Fe 0.31
)
2
O 3
$(\mathrm{In}_{0.69}\mathrm{Fe}_{0.31})_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ film tend to be similar to those of Fe metal, indicating the existence of Fe metal clusters in the film.
Fig. 1
(a) The Fe K-edge XANES spectra of
(

)
2
O 3
$(\mathrm{In}_{1-x}\mathrm{Fe}_{x})_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ (
x = 0.07 , 0.09 , 0.16 , 0.22 , 0.31
$x=0.07, 0.09, 0.16, 0.22, 0.31$ ) films as well as Fe, FeO,
Fe 2

Figure 1(b) shows the enlarged view of pre-edge absorption features of XANES spectra. One can see that the XANES spectra of the
(
In
1 − x
Fe x
)
2
O 3
$(\mathrm{In}_{1-x}\mathrm{Fe}_{x})_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ films with
x = 0.07 , 0.09 , 0.16
$x=0.07, 0.09, 0.16$ lie between that of FeO and
Fe 2
O 3
$\mathrm{Fe}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ , revealing that the Fe average oxidation states range between
+ 2
$+2$ and
+ 3
$+3$ . That is to say, there exists a mixed-valence state (
Fe
2 +
/
Fe
3 +
$\mathrm{Fe}^{2+}/\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$ ) of Fe ions in these films. In addition, a clear 1s–3d pre-edge absorption peak around 7711 eV, typical of Fe ions in octahedral coordination of oxygen atoms, is observed. The pre-edge peak position is virtually unchanged, but the intensity gradually increases with the increase of Fe concentration, especially for the
(
In
1 − x
Fe x
)
2
O 3
$(\mathrm{In}_{1-x}\mathrm{Fe}_{x})_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ film with
x = 0.16
$x=0.16$ . Theoretically, the pre-edge peak arises from a strictly dipole forbidden 1s–3d transition and its intensity increases with the degree of asymmetry and disorder around the central TM ions, which results in the Fe 3d and O 2p orbital mixing that causes the dipole-allowed transition [21, 22]. So the intensity change of the pre-edge peaks implies that the degree of asymmetry and disorder around the Fe ions is enhanced. Interstitial Fe atoms or very small Fe metal clusters also may be responsible for such features; this needs to be further confirmed by EXAFS. As for the films with high Fe concentration (
x ≥ 0.22
$x\geq0.22$ ), the intensity of pre-edge peak obviously increases and a shoulder peak is observed in comparison with the pre-edge feature of Fe metal, strongly suggesting the existence of Fe metal clusters.

Multiple EXAFS scans were taken at room temperature in the range 7000–7750 eV. Theoretically, the EXAFS oscillations have been fitted to the well-known expression [23, 24]: 1
χ ( k )

$$\begin{aligned} \chi(k) =&\sum_{j}\frac{N_{j}}{kR^{2}_{j}}S^{2}_{0}F_{j}(k) \exp\bigl(+2\sigma^{2}_{j}k^{2}\bigr) \exp \bigl[-2R_{j}/\lambda(k)\bigr] \\ &{}\times \sin\bigl[2kR_{j}+\delta_{ij}(k)\bigr] \end{aligned}$$ which describes the EXAFS oscillations for a distribution of atoms around the absorber, considering single scattering and a plane-wave approximation.
N j
$N_{j}$ is the average coordination number of neighbor;
R j
$R_{j}$ is the near-neighbor distance;
σ j
$\sigma_{j}$ is the Debye–Waller factor in the
j
$j$ th shell around the absorber;
F j
( k )
$F_{j}(k)$ is the magnitude of the backscattering amplitude;
S 0 2
$S_{0}^{2}$ is the amplitude reduction factor;
λ j
( k )
$\lambda_{j}(k)$ is the mean-free path of the scattered photoelectron traveling from the absorbing atom to the backscattering in the
j
$j$ th shell mean-free path of electron;
δ j
( k )
$\delta_{j}(k)$ is the total phase shift experienced by the scattered photoelectron.

The three strong peaks at around 1.51, 2.66 and 3.18 Å correspond to the first, the second and the third nearest neighbor coordination shell of Fe. The position of these peaks is obviously different from Fe metal (2.24 and 3.63 Å),

In 1

(

R
$R$ ), coordination number (
N
$N$ ), and Debye–Waller factors (
σ 2
$\sigma^{2}$ ) of different atomic shells are given in Table 1. Within experimental error, the Fe–O bond length of films is much smaller than the In–O bond length (2.19 Å) in pure
In 2
O 3
$\mathrm{In}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ , which is in qualitative agreement with the smaller radius of Fe ions, as compared to In ions. With the increase of Fe concentration, the shortening of the Fe–O bond length and the increase of Debye–Waller (DW) factor (
σ 2
$\sigma ^{2}$ ) in the first coordination shell are observed; these effects can be attributed to the relaxation of oxygen environment of Fe ions upon substitution, but this relaxation does not largely distort the second Fe–In coordination shell and leads to the obvious increase in the corresponding DW factor. As for the
(
In
1 − x
Fe x
)
2
O 3
$(\mathrm{In}_{1-x}\mathrm{Fe}_{x})_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ (
x = 0.22 , 0.31

≤ 3
${\leq}3$ ) effective coordination number. It is remarkable that the
(
In
1 − x
Fe x
)
2
O 3
$(\mathrm{In}_{1-x}\mathrm{Fe}_{x})_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ film with
x = 0.31
$x=0.31$ shows the largest static local disorder with a very short Fe–O distance of 1.94 Å.

p
1 / 2
$2\mathrm{p}_{1 /2}$ ) states to the continuum of empty 3d states (strictly speaking, transition to a hybridized state of Fe 3d and O 2p). The large energy separation is due to spin-orbit splitting of the 2p core-hole [25]. The
L
2 , 3
$\mathrm{L}_{2,3}$ -edge XAS spectra of all films exhibit a double-peak characteristic (marked by an arrow in Fig. 4). The atomic multiple features result from Coulomb and exchange interactions of the 2p core holes with the 3d electrons and are typical for localized 3d states [26].

2 +

L 3

Fe 2
O 3
$\mathrm{Fe}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ , especially for the
(
In 0.69
Fe 0.31
)
2
O 3
$(\mathrm{In}_{0.69}\mathrm{Fe}_{0.31})_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ film with a broad shoulder peak B at about 711 eV, which is 1.5 eV lower in energy than peak A. Mixed valence states in the films often lead to a significant broadening in XAS spectra, such as found in (La,Ca)MnO3 and MnSi crystalline compounds [27, 28]. In (La,Ca)MnO3, the L-edge broadening is considered as the coexistence of Mn3+ and Mn4+ sites. In order to obtain a better insight into the valence state of Fe ions, a linear combination fitting the reference spectra using weighted averages of Fe metal, FeO and
Fe 2
O 3
$\mathrm{Fe}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ was carried out, as shown in Fig. 6. It is observed that the
L 3
$\mathrm{L}_{3}$ -edge spectrum of the
(
In 0.84
Fe 0.16
)
2

Fe 2
O 3
$\mathrm{Fe}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ spectra are included, with a ratio of about 3:2 (
Fe
2 +
:
Fe

(

∼ 40

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para:
In summary, the influence of Fe doping on the local structure of
(
In
1 − x
Fe x
)
2
O 3
$(\mathrm{In}_{1-x}\mathrm{Fe}_{x})_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ (
x = 0.07 , 0.09 , 0.16 , 0.22 , 0.31
$x=0.07, 0.09, 0.16, 0.22, 0.31$ ) films prepared by RF-magnetron sputtering technique has been studied by X-ray absorption spectroscopy at Fe K-edge and
L
2 , 3
$\mathrm{L}_{2,3}$ -edge. The detailed analysis of the structural properties suggests that for the films with low Fe concentration (
x ≤ 0.16
$x\leq0.16$ ), Fe ions are in mixed valence state of
Fe
2 +
/
Fe
3 +
$\mathrm{Fe}^{2+}/\mathrm{Fe}^{3 +}$ with a ratio of
∼ 3 : 2 (
Fe
2 +
:
Fe
3 +
)
${\sim}3:2 (\mathrm{Fe}^{2+}: \mathrm{Fe}^{3+})$ , substituting at the In sites of
In 2
O 3
$\mathrm{In}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ lattice. The Fe–O bond length shortens and the corresponding Debye–Waller factor (
σ 2
$\sigma^{2}$ ) increases with the increase of Fe concentration, indicating the relaxation of oxygen environment of Fe ions upon substitution. With further increasing of Fe concentration (
x = 0.22 , 0.31
$x=0.22, 0.31$ ), Fe metal clusters appear and the anomalously large structural disorder and also a very short Fe–O distance are observed, especially for the
(
In
1 − x
Fe x
)
2
O 3
$(\mathrm{In}_{1-x}\mathrm{Fe}_{x})_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ films with
x = 0.31
$x=0.31$ , approximately 40 % of Fe precipitates into metallic aggregates.
